traces.name: 2_fail_median_delta_only
traces.description: ‚ùå FAIL - Median delta check: median shifted by +56ms (threshold: 50ms, CV ~6%). Demonstrates median regression detection with mixed timing to stay under directionality threshold.

traces.name: 3_fail_tail_p90_only
traces.description: ‚ùå FAIL - Tail latency (p90) check: p90 degraded by +90ms while median shifted only +7ms (under 50ms threshold, CV ~10%). Demonstrates importance of monitoring worst-case performance for SLOs.

traces.name: 4_fail_directionality_only
traces.description: ‚ùå FAIL - Directionality check: 100% of runs slower than baseline median (threshold: 70%). Demonstrates detection of consistent small slowdowns.

traces.name: 5_fail_mann_whitney_only
traces.description: ‚ùå FAIL - Mann-Whitney U test: uniform distribution shift detected (p < 0.05, CV ~3%). Demonstrates statistical testing catches significant distributional changes even with small median deltas.

traces.name: 6_inconclusive_high_variance
traces.description: ‚ö†Ô∏è INCONCLUSIVE - High variance: CV > 15% indicates unreliable data. Demonstrates quality gate protection.

traces.name: 7_inconclusive_insufficient_samples
traces.description: ‚ö†Ô∏è INCONCLUSIVE - Insufficient samples: only 5 samples (need 10+). Demonstrates sample size requirement.

traces.name: 8_directionality_vs_mann_whitney_bimodal
traces.description:
üéØ DEMONSTRATES DIFFERENCE - Bimodal distribution (half faster, half slower):

Baseline: All exactly 100ms (zero variance)
Target: 6 samples at 99ms (faster), 6 samples at 105ms (slower)
Median: target=102ms vs baseline=100ms (+2ms)

üìä CHECK RESULTS:
‚Ä¢ Directionality: 6/12 = 50% slower ‚Üí PASS ‚úÖ (< 70% threshold)
  - Only half the samples exceeded baseline median
  - Simple count-based approach says "not enough slow samples"

‚Ä¢ Mann-Whitney: p ‚âà 0.51 ‚Üí PASS ‚úÖ 
  - U-statistic = 72 (half beat baseline, half don't)
  - 50/50 split is not statistically significant
  - Distribution-based approach confirms no significant shift

üí° KEY INSIGHT: Both checks PASS here, but they measure fundamentally different things:
‚Ä¢ Directionality: "Did 70%+ cross the baseline median?" (threshold-based)
‚Ä¢ Mann-Whitney: "Is the overall distribution statistically different?" (rank-based)

In this case, the bimodal split (6 faster, 6 slower) is NOT a regression - it's just variance. Both checks correctly identify this, but through different mathematical approaches. This proves they're measuring different aspects, even when results align.

traces.name: 9_directionality_vs_mann_whitney_tiny_shift
traces.description:
üéØ DEMONSTRATES DIFFERENCE - Tiny consistent +0.8ms shift across ALL samples:

Baseline: 98-102ms (median=100ms, normal variance)
Target: Each sample shifted +0.8ms higher
Median: target=100.8ms vs baseline=100ms (+0.8ms)

üìä CHECK RESULTS:
‚Ä¢ Directionality: ~83-92% slower ‚Üí FAIL ‚ùå (> 70% threshold)
  - Almost all samples exceeded baseline median of 100ms
  - VERY sensitive to even tiny upward shifts
  - Sees: "83% of samples crossed the line!"

‚Ä¢ Mann-Whitney: p ‚âà 0.02 ‚Üí FAIL ‚ùå
  - Detects statistically significant shift
  - But considers magnitude: is 0.8ms meaningful?
  - More nuanced than simple percentage

üí° KEY INSIGHT: Both FAIL, but for different reasons:
‚Ä¢ Directionality is OVERLY SENSITIVE: flags any shift affecting >70% of samples, regardless of magnitude
‚Ä¢ Mann-Whitney is MORE NUANCED: considers statistical significance of the shift

In practice, this 0.8ms shift might trigger:
- Directionality: FAIL (too many samples crossed)
- Mann-Whitney: FAIL (statistically significant)
- Practical Significance: PASS (0.8ms < 2ms threshold)

This shows why we need ALL checks - Directionality catches breadth, Mann-Whitney catches statistical significance, Practical Significance catches real-world impact!

traces.name: 10_directionality_vs_mann_whitney_tail_problem
traces.description:
üéØ DEMONSTRATES DIFFERENCE - Tail latency problem (majority fast, minority VERY slow):

Baseline: All exactly 100ms (n=15, zero variance)
Target: 9 samples FASTER (97-99ms), 5 samples MUCH SLOWER (115-125ms)
Median: target=99ms vs baseline=100ms (-1ms, median improved!)

üìä CHECK RESULTS:
‚Ä¢ Directionality: 5/14 = 36% slower ‚Üí PASS ‚úÖ (< 70% threshold)
  - Only 36% of samples exceeded baseline median (100ms)
  - Majority (64%) are actually FASTER
  - Simple count says: "Most samples are fine, no problem"

‚Ä¢ Mann-Whitney: p ‚âà 0.85 ‚Üí PASS ‚úÖ
  - Even though 5 samples are +15-25ms slower
  - The 9 faster samples dominate the distribution
  - Not enough evidence of overall shift

‚Ä¢ Tail Latency (P90): Should show +15-25ms degradation ‚Üí FAIL ‚ùå
  - P90 latency: baseline=100ms, target‚âà120ms
  - This is the check that catches this problem!

üí° KEY INSIGHT: This scenario demonstrates WHY we need MULTIPLE checks:
‚Ä¢ Directionality: MISSES the tail problem (only 36% affected)
‚Ä¢ Mann-Whitney: MISSES the tail problem (9 fast samples dominate)
‚Ä¢ Tail Latency (P90): CATCHES the tail problem (worst-case degraded)

Real-world impact:
- Median: Improved (-1ms) ‚úÖ
- Most requests: Faster ‚úÖ  
- Worst-case (P90+): MUCH SLOWER ‚ùå ‚Üê SLA violation!

This is a classic tail latency regression that requires dedicated tail monitoring. Directionality and Mann-Whitney are NOT duplicates - they're both median-focused checks that complement the tail latency check.
